awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Paper Mechatronics: Creating High-Low Tech Design Kits to Promote Engineering Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies Program funds efforts that support envisioning the future of learning technologies and advance what we know about how people learn in technology-rich environments. In this Cyberlearning EAGER project, the project team is developing foundations for using "paper mechatronics" as a learning technology. Paper mechatronics makes possible a craft-oriented approach to engineering and computing education that integrates key concepts from mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, control systems, and computer programming, while using paper as the primary material for learner design, exploration, and inquiry. In this approach, learners will design foldable paper components and assemblies; program motors, sensors and controls; test their ideas iteratively; and share their designs on a website. This paper-based modeling approach to learning concepts in and practices of mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, control systems, and computer programming ultimately aims to make it possible for all learners to have exposure to and the opportunity to participate in creative engineering, design, and computer programming.

The approach to learning through designing and making through paper mechatronics is made possible by a convergence of many different technological factors -- the array of small computers, sensors, and actuators that are becoming available at low cost and a size that children can use; availability of a wide variety of manipulable conductive materials (threads, paints, fabrics); low-cost and precise desktop and laser cutters for paper and similar materials; a wide variety of novel paper-like materials; and new ways of interacting with the computer. The approach has its foundations in Papert's constructionism and in the current maker movement, but it has potential beyond constructionism itself, both in practice and with respect to what can potentially be learned about learning and development in in context of its use. During the course of the proposed project, the team is addressing a variety of issues -- theoretical (e.g., extending the constructionist approach to take into account the kinds of embodied experiences children can have with the proposed kinds of materials), disciplinary (e.g., which disciplinary content learning and interdisciplinary connection making might this kind of making best support and for which populations), technological, and pragmatic ones. They will identify both the design goals and the research questions that it makes the most sense to take on in a more mature project. Work on this project will lay the foundations for extending theories of computationally-based expressive technologies, design of constructionist-oriented learning environments, and assessing creativity, self-efficacy, engagement, and conceptual understanding of electro-mechanical systems with school-aged learners,

por.por_cntn:
Paper Mechatronics is a strikingly novel craft-oriented approach to engineering education–one that integrates key concepts from mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, control systems, and computer programming while using paper as the primary substrate material for learner exploration and inquiry. This exploratory project (a) prototyped, designed, and developed “Paper Mechatronics” – computationally-enabled paper projects and activities that act as "objects-to-think-with", (b) gathered formative feedback from different learner participants to assess its effectiveness, and (c) articulated and refined a set of research questions to advance future design-based research and implementation studies.

This NSF EAGER project is a collaboration of the Craft Technology Lab at CU Boulder, the Concord Consortium, UC Berkeley Lawrence Hall of Science, and the Correll Robotics Lab at CU Boulder.  Paper Mechatronics developed open source software (FoldMecha) that supported learners in designing foldable paper components and assemblies. The project also integrated programmable kit-based hardware components to enable control of motors, sensing, and feedback as well as developed workshops and program formats like Robot Petting Zoos to test paper mechatronic prototypes with different audiences.

 

This paper-based modeling approach to learning mechatronics ultimately aims to give all learners the exposure and opportunity to participate in creative engineering. This project focuses on the rapid prototyping and design of Paper Mechatronics materials concurrent with formative research. The project engages learners and educators from local schools, public science centers, and before/aftercare/summer programs to test and improve the activities and approach. Furthermore, the work extends theories of computationally-based expressive technologies to inform and help advance future research on design for learning electro-mechanical systems with school-aged learners.

 

Intellectual Merit. There are two major areas of intellectual merit in this project. The first is on the technical dimension: the project has arguably pioneered a variety of paper-based engineering techniques. For instance, in one recent prototype, pleating patterns were used in combination with computational elements to create automatic “crumpling” mechanical motions that would be hard to implement in a material like metal or wood. In another recent project, laser cut pieces of cardboard were used to create a working paper differential. In other words, the project has worked toward not only using paper to imitate other materials, but to promote engineering ideas that exploit the features of this material. The second, educational dimension has focused on expanding children’s engineering to encompass the aesthetic, creative, and “construction-friendly” features of paper, and to thereby attract students who are less entranced by the culture or aesthetics of (e.g.) classical robotics or circuit design. Depending on the chosen instructional emphasis, paper mechatronics can be flexibly used as a context for learning elements of mechanical design, understanding computer programming, and/or for teaching sensing and controls.


Broader Impacts. Maker clubs, robotics, and programming competitions are a dominant approach to learning design and engineering, especially among boys in well-resourced communities. Paper mechatronics explores an alternative genre using papercrafts and cyberlearning tools to empower learners to imagine, construct, and iteratively build their understanding through hands-on projects, computationally-enabled design, and construction. Because of the flexibility and interdisciplinarity of paper mechatronics – and because of the ubiquity and accessibility of paper and cardboard, and the uniquely creative and expressive nature of computationally-enhanced papercrafts – this project is potentially transformative for a wide range of audiences, including learners, educators, researchers, and developers and publishers of instructional materials across all STEM grades. During the two year exploratory project, participants reached have included K12 teachers, afterschool educators, families, museum visitors, teens, and urban middle school girls. Paper mechatronics could plausibly offer an alternative pathway to learning engineering, computer science, and robotics, offer an educational and creative innovation that can spread widely, helping to provide all states with a solution to address the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and engineering especially for underserved groups.
